newsitem.title: JAPAN: Yaohan Japan to shift clerical staff to stores.
newsitem.headline: Yaohan Japan to shift clerical staff to stores.

text.p: Japanese retailer Yaohan Japan Corp said on Thursday that it would shift half of its administrative work force into store jobs by the end of 1997/98 as part of restructuring measures.
Yaohan currently employs about 400 workers for back-office operations at its headquarters and affiliate firms, half of which will be redeployed in its stores.

A Yaohan spokesman said the company's vice chairman Terumasa Wada will resign when the company holds a stockholders' meeting in June to take responsibility for a deterioration in the company's financial condition.
Yaohan Japan, the flagship firm of the Yaohan international retailing group, has been burdened with hefty borrowings after aggressive expansion overseas.
The company said in February that it plans to trim group debt subject to interest payments to 90 billion yen from 164.6 billion yen by the end of March 1999.
Yaohan also said in February that it has agreed with supermarket chain operator Daiei Inc to sell 16 of its outlets for 33 billion yen.

The two companies said in separate statements that the 16 outlets, all in central Japan, would be sold to Seifu Kabushiki Kaisha, a chainstore operator owned 89.8 percent by Daiei, in the middle of May.
The spokesman said that Yaohan's British subsidiary Yaohan Development U.K. Ltd may sell off its shopping centre located in a suburb of London as part of efforts to reduce the group's debts.
